Problem:
Consider a continuous function \\(z(t)\\) defined on the complex plane, governed by \\(\\frac{dz}{dt} = i\\omega z + k\\), where \\(\\omega\\) and \\(k\\) are constants, and \\(i\\) is the imaginary unit. Suppose we apply the transformation \\(g(z) = e^{\\alpha t}z\\) periodically at times \\(t_n = nT\\), where \\(n\\) is an integer and \\(T\\) a constant interval.

If the transformation \\(g(z)\\) is applied to an initial state \\(z_0\\) at \\(t = 0\\) and then the system is allowed to evolve under the given differential equation without further intervention, will the state \\(z(T)\\) be the same as without applying \\(g(z)\\)?
Explanation: The transformation \\(g(z)\\) modifies the initial condition, scaling it by \\(e^{\\alpha T}\\). The evolution of \\(z(t)\\) under the differential equation from this new initial state results in a different trajectory and endpoint at \\(t = T\\), due to the exponential factor introduced, which scales the magnitude and rotates the phase of the complex number.
